147492991.review:
This mouse overlay app is the best one I've ever used!

Different mouse designs and colours can be set for different software programs i.e. games and then you can even set different designs & colours for different aspects within the same software.
For example you can set a cursor for navigating a games user interface then set a completely different one for when targeting items in a game or an enemy. Once more this can be easily done by mousing over something like an item and then using a quick keyboard shortcut and boom its set, then with additional keyboard shortcuts you can the size and colour.

Overall very impressed, highlights:

* Several Different mouse designs.
* Wide range of colours.
* Varied sizes.
* Customise cursors for differ software programs.
* Customise different courses for different functions within the same software.
* Customisable keyboard shortcuts.
* Low Memory and CPU utilisation. 
For me it's 5.4 MB RAM and 0.1-0.2% CPU utilisation when running, It does increase however if you load up the YOLO UI to do any config to the app itself e.i. to change keyboard shortcuts but it goes back down again when the UI is closed.

Again very impressed.

It's easy for YoloMouse to stand out when a game's own high contrast or high visibility cursors are hilariously bad in comparison.

As an unlisted "feature", you can set the hidden cursor to a circle (or any custom cursor of your choosing) as a makeshift crosshair. In most cases, the custom cursor will be centered when the mouse is set to free look and of course for the best result make sure the game's own crosshair is hidden. Try it. Apparently there's another utility software for custom crosshairs but this has worked well for me.

For practical reasons, I also suggest unchecking "sync with Steam".

113436285.review: Here's why this tool is useful: It's really easy to lose your crosshair in certain games if the game developers don't implement different crosshairs to compensate for it. Sometimes, your white crosshair will disappear in snow environments if the devs don't compensate for it by turning it black. Or maybe you're in an intense situation and your crosshair isn't noticeable enough when there's too much other stuff going on. This fixes that. It's a niche problem, but it's a problem that arises enough to be worth the money. I personally always use the crosshair color that inverts what colors are behind the crosshair. That way, my crosshair will always stand out no matter where or when it's being used.

94372647.developer_response:
cursor menu to replace hotkeys coming next patch :)... as for black screen problem, its due to a particular nvidia setting:

Black screen
If you see a black screen and have an NVIDIA GPU, open NVIDIA Control Panel: 3D Settings: Adjust Image Settings and ensure Let application decide is selected. Alternatively in Manage 3D settings disable Antialiasing - FXAA. It's also recommended not to use GeForce Experience.

[hr][/hr]
[h1] YoloMouse[/h1]
[i]YoloMouse is a neat little piece of software that allows you to change your ingame cursor for more visability. I've personally been using the non-steam version of it for Path of Exile for quite some time and it really helps me keep track of my character in such a chaotic game. [/i]

[h1] Custom Cursors[/h1]
While it is possible to add custom cursors it could use some work. Currently to add custom cursors you have to;
[olist]
[*] Collect your .CUR or .ANI files and rename them to numbers between 0 and 89 (Example: 12.ANI).
[*] Copy them to YoloMouse\Cursors.
[*] Restart yolomouse.
[*] Test using CTRL ALT 1 and CTRL ALT 3.
[/olist]
[h1] Stuff I'd love to see added to YoloMouse[/h1]
[list]
[*] Easier adding of custom cursors
[i]A small thing, but would be useful.[/i]
[*] Add an option to not have the "in game"
[i]While the software currently has it, it only works if you have start with windows checked. Which I'm not interested in.[/i]
[*] Steam Achievements
[i]I just personally like achievement systems, even if it is software. Kinda like Wallpaper engine, it encourages me to explore the software.[/i]
[/list]
[h1]TLDR;[/h1]
[i]A neat software if you play chaotic games where you loose track of your character / cursor. [/i]

[b]EDIT:[/b] 
I love how great this developer is at responding to reviews, let's me know it's been seen. Great work! 

[hr][/hr]

This program very useful for when you need to target the ground in MMO's like Guild Wars 2, since the cursor is often hard to follow while you're doing other stuff. 
You just press the hotkey when your game is displaying a cursor, and then the cursor gets replaced with a YoloMouse cursor which can be resized or have the colour changed. It's pretty easy to use for games where you might lose track of your cursor. 

The YoloMouse cursors aren't exactly very attractive, though, and I would like to see a possibility to have themed cursors that correspond to common game cursors - e.i. thematically and graphically consistent cursors replacing cursors you often find in games. For example, there's no speech bubble cursor in YoloMouse. 

But when you just need to click somewhere precisely and quickly without having to track down your tiny in-game cursor, YoloMouse is great.

75331307.review:
Yolo mouse is AMAZING. I've been struggling to play some older titles at 1440p (and soon to be 4K) because the mouse cursors are so small, it's hard to keep track of in RTS games.

Using Yolo mouse is as easy as downloading it, launching it, launching whatever game you want and increasing the cursor size (which increases the in-game cursor, so you don't have to use one of the pre-installed cursors that don't match the game's aesthetic). 

Even better, Yolo mouse automatically keeps separate profiles for every game you use it with. So my desktop cursor remains the same size I want, then I can launch a game like Dawn of War and the cursor will automatically change to the last cursor size I set. Then when I'm done and exit the game, the cursor reverts to the normal desktop cursor. Frankly, this is absolutely phenomenal because, as our lord and savior Todd Howard has said, "It just works."

68517199.developer_response:
Hi Godsdemon

Just tested with DAOC. This is one of the few games that require YM to be run as administrator. You can enable this under yolomouse taskbar icon -> Run as Administrator. Afterwards revisit DAOC and hit CTRL ALT 1 (or 2) again.

There is one bug noticed here is that you should see a message telling you to do this, but it doesnt show up in DAOC, which I noted and will be fixed.

Note that currently run as admin does not persist between reboots. We're working on adding this next patch

Cheers :)
